ByzSecAgg: A Byzantine-Resistant Secure Aggregation Scheme for Federated Learning Based on Coded Computing and Vector Commitment

Tayyebeh Jahani-Nezhad Mohammad Ali Maddah-Ali and Giuseppe Caire T. Jahani-Nezhad and G. Caire are with the Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department, Technische Universität Berlin, 10587 Berlin, Germany (e-mail: t.jahani.nezhad@tu-berlin.de, caire@tu-berlin.de) M. A. Maddah-ali are with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Minnesota, Twin Cities (e-mail: maddah@umn.edu)
Abstract

In this paper, we propose ByzSecAgg, an efficient secure aggregation scheme for federated learning that is protected against Byzantine attacks and privacy leakages. Processing individual updates to manage adversarial behavior, while preserving privacy of data against colluding nodes, requires some sort of secure secret sharing. However, the communication load for secret sharing of long vectors of updates can be very high. ByzSecAgg solves this problem by partitioning local updates into smaller sub-vectors and sharing them using ramp secret sharing. However, this sharing method does not admit bi-linear computations, such as pairwise distance calculations, needed by outlier-detection algorithms. To overcome this issue, each user runs another round of ramp sharing, with different embedding of data in the sharing polynomial. This technique, motivated by ideas from coded computing, enables secure computation of pairwise distance. In addition, to maintain the integrity and privacy of the local update, ByzSecAgg also uses a vector commitment method, in which the commitment size remains constant (i.e. does not increase with the length of the local update), while simultaneously allowing verification of the secret sharing process. In terms of communication loads, ByzSecAgg significantly outperforms the state-of-the-art scheme, known as BREA.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, Secure aggregation, Byzantine-robustness, Vector Commitment.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is an emerging distributed learning framework that allows a group of distributed users (e.g., mobile devices) to collaboratively train a global model with their local private data, without sharing the data [1, 2, 3]. Specifically, in a FL system with a central server and several users, during each training iteration, the server sends the current state of the global model to the users. Receiving the global model, each user then calculates a local update with its local data, and sends the local update to the server. By aggregating the local updates, the server can update the global model for the next iteration. While the local datasets are not directly shared with the server, several studies have shown that a curious server can launch model inversion attacks to reveal information about the training data of the individual users from their local updates [4, 5]. Therefore, the key challenge to protect users’ data privacy is to design secure aggregation protocols, which allow the aggregation of the local updates to be computed without revealing each individual data. Moreover, as some users may randomly drop out of the aggregation process (due to low batteries or unstable connections), the server should be able to robustly recover the aggregated local updates of the surviving users in a privacy-preserving manner.

As such motivated, a secure aggregation protocol SecAgg is proposed in [6]. In SecAgg, the local updates are masked before being sent to the server, using the private and shared random vectors, such that the shared parts can be canceled out when aggregated. One of the major challenges for SecAgg is the communication load, which grows quadratically with the number of users. There has been a series of works aiming to improve the communication efficiency of SecAgg (see, e.g., [7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13]). For instance, SwiftAgg+, recently proposed in [14], significantly reduces the communication overheads without any compromise on worst-case information-theoretic security, and achieves optimal communication loads within diminishing gaps for secure aggregation.

In [7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14], the honest-but-curious model for secure aggregation is considered in which users correctly follow the protocol but some of them may try to gather information about other users’ private information, potentially through collusion. However, some studies have also addressed the malicious model in which Byzantine adversaries have more capabilities and may run poisoning attacks, i.e., manipulate their inputs to change the outcome of the aggregation [15, 16, 17]. The problem of robustness against Byzantine adversaries in distributed and federated learning is well-researched in two categories: distance-based methods [18, 19, 20, 21] and validation data-based methods [22, 23]. However, those defenses come with some potential privacy issues, as they require the server to process the local model updates.

As a Byzantine resistant secure aggregation scheme, in [24], BREA is proposed in which users share their model updates with others using Shamir secret sharing and then calculate the pairwise distance between the received shares. The server then uses this information to identify and exclude Byzantine users from the aggregation process. BREA suffers from two major shortcomings: (1) to verify secret sharing, in BREA every single element of data is committed separately, (2) The secret sharing is not designed efficiently. As a result, the loads of commitment and sharing grow linearly with the aggregated size of all local updates. An alternative approach is proposed in [25], which involves grouping users anonymously and randomly into subgroups with a hierarchical tree structure. The aggregation method similar to SecAgg is performed within each subgroup, and then the process repeats at the next level of subgroups toward the root. The anonymity and randomness of the grouping reduce the probability of successful Byzantine attacks, as attackers do not know which subgroup the compromised device belongs to. However, in that approach, smaller subgroups result in reduced privacy for participants, while larger subgroups make it easier for the Byzantine attacker to hide their malicious model among the honest ones. In [26], a similar idea is proposed, which involves repeating the random grouping multiple times to save more updates of benign users through robust aggregation. However, that approach increases the communication loads and also reveals some information about the local updates. In [27], ELSA is proposed, which utilizes a distributed trust setup where two servers in separate trust domains work together to emulate the role of a central coordinating server. Each iteration begins with two servers selecting a group of users to participate and sharing the current global model with them. These users then use the cryptography module to securely share their local updates with the two servers. The servers then use an interactive protocol to combine these updates and find the aggregation.

In this paper, we propose ByzSecAgg, a scheme for Byzantine-robust secure aggregation in a federated learning setting with a single server. The proposed scheme reduces the communication loads, and is robust against user dropouts, collusion and Byzantine adversarial attacks, and it involves the following steps:

  • •

    Each user partitions its local update vector into smaller sub-vectors and broadcasts constant-size commitments of them, regardless of the size of the local update. This ensures that the sub-vectors can be proven to be unchanged during the scheme, while still keeping them hidden.

  • •

    Users securely share these sub-vectors with others using ramp secret sharing, and these shares can be verified using the commitments.

  • •

    Each user creates another polynomial function to send additional shares of their sub-vectors to other users, allowing for the computation of pairwise distance of shares through coded computing.

  • •

    The server then uses these pairwise distances of shares to recover the pairwise distances of the true local updates. Using these distances, the server employs a distance-based outlier detection algorithm to select a subset of users for aggregation.

  • •

    Finally, the server obtains the aggregation of local updates of the selected users by communicating with the users who locally aggregate the secret shares of the model updates that belong to the selected users.

ByzSecAgg ensures the privacy of individual local models by performing computations using secret shares, which prevent users from learning the true values of local updates. Additionally, the server is not able to obtain any information about the local models beyond the aggregation and the pairwise distances. Furthermore, the commitments in ByzSecAgg are binding and computationally hiding. This means that users cannot obtain any information from the commitments, but they are still able to verify the authenticity of the messages received from others and validity of sharings.

Table I shows the comparison between the baseline framework BREA in [24] and ByzSecAgg in terms of the communication loads. For a fair comparison, we consider three metrics: the server communication load, the per-user communication load and the commitments size. Server communication indicates the total size of all messages which are sent or received by the server, per-user communication denotes the total size of all messages which are sent by each user, and the commitments size represents the size of commitments made by users required for message verification. Compared with the baseline, as shown in Table I, in the system consisting of N𝑁N users, ByzSecAgg reduces server and per-user communication loads, as well as significantly decreasing commitment size. The proposed scheme allows for K𝐾K, a design parameter, to be in the range [1:N−D+12−A−T]delimited-[]:1𝑁𝐷12𝐴𝑇[1:\frac{N-D+1}{2}-A-T], where D,T𝐷𝑇D,T and A𝐴A denote the maximum number of dropouts, colluding users, and Byzantine adversaries, respectively, for which the scheme is designed. Based on system parameters N𝑁N and L𝐿L, which is the size of each local update, the optimal value of K𝐾K for minimizing communication loads can be chosen. For instance, for large L𝐿L, in extreme case we can choose K=𝒪​(N)𝐾𝒪𝑁K=\mathcal{O}(N), which significantly decreases the server and per-user communication loads. Note that in the special case when K=1𝐾1K=1, the server and per-user communication loads in ByzSecAgg are equivalent to those in BREA. However, unlike BREA, the commitment size remains constant in ByzSecAgg, regardless of the size of local updates.

II Problem formulation

We consider the Byzantine-robust secure aggregation problem, for a federated learning system, consisting of a server and N𝑁N users. The objective of the server is to train a global model 𝐰g∈ℝLsubscript𝐰𝑔superscriptℝ𝐿\mathbf{w}_{g}\in\mathbb{R}^{L}, with dimension L∈ℕ𝐿ℕL\in\mathbb{N}, using the data held at users, by minimizing a global cost function 𝔏​(𝐰g)𝔏subscript𝐰𝑔\mathfrak{L}(\mathbf{w}_{g}). In round t𝑡t of the training phase, the server broadcasts the global model 𝐰g(t)∈ℝLsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑡superscriptℝ𝐿\mathbf{w}_{g}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{R}^{L} to all users. Then each user n𝑛n, n∈[N]𝑛delimited-[]𝑁n\in[N] computes a private local update 𝐰n∈ℝLsubscript𝐰𝑛superscriptℝ𝐿\mathbf{w}_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{L} based on its private local dataset. In this paper, we focus on perfect secure aggregation schemes, which rely on operations in a finite field to protect the privacy of the local updates [12, 14, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 13]. Consider that each user employs an element-wise stochastic quantization method that involves a rounding function Q:ℝ→ℝ:𝑄→ℝℝQ:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} and a mapping function Λ:ℝ→𝔽:Λ→ℝ𝔽\Lambda:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{F}, which maps the integer numbers to elements of a finite field 𝔽𝔽\mathbb{F}. The finite field is considered large enough to prevent hitting the boundary in the process of aggregation.

User n𝑛n also has a collection of local random variables 𝒵nsubscript𝒵𝑛\mathcal{Z}_{n}, whose elements are selected uniformly at random from 𝔽Lsuperscript𝔽𝐿\mathbb{F}^{L}, and independently of each other and of the local updates. It is assumed that each user has an authenticated broadcast channel through which messages can be sent and received by all users. Additionally, it is assumed that each user has an error-free point-to-point communication link to every other user and the server. Let 𝐌n→n′(L)∈𝔽∗∪{⟂}subscriptsuperscript𝐌𝐿→𝑛superscript𝑛′superscript𝔽perpendicular-to\mathbf{M}^{(L)}_{n\to n^{\prime}}\in\mathbb{F}^{*}\cup\{\perp\} denote the message that user n𝑛n sends to user n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime} in finite field 𝔽𝔽\mathbb{F} in the algorithm. In addition, let 𝐗n(L)∈𝔽∗∪{⟂}subscriptsuperscript𝐗𝐿𝑛superscript𝔽perpendicular-to\mathbf{X}^{(L)}_{n}\in\mathbb{F}^{*}\cup\{\perp\} denote the message sent by user n𝑛n to the server. The null symbol ⟂perpendicular-to\perp represents the case no message is sent. Here 𝔽∗=∪ℓ∈ℕ𝔽ℓsuperscript𝔽subscriptℓℕsuperscript𝔽ℓ\mathbb{F}^{*}=\cup_{\ell\in\mathbb{N}}\mathbb{F}^{\ell}. The message 𝐌n→n′(L)subscriptsuperscript𝐌𝐿→𝑛superscript𝑛′\mathbf{M}^{(L)}_{n\to n^{\prime}} is a function of 𝐰nsubscript𝐰𝑛\mathbf{w}_{n}, 𝒵nsubscript𝒵𝑛\mathcal{Z}_{n}. We denote the corresponding encoding function by ϕn→n′(L)subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝐿→𝑛superscript𝑛′\phi^{(L)}_{n\to n^{\prime}}. Similarly, 𝐗n(L)subscriptsuperscript𝐗𝐿𝑛\mathbf{X}^{(L)}_{n} is a function of 𝐰nsubscript𝐰𝑛\mathbf{w}_{n}, 𝒵nsubscript𝒵𝑛\mathcal{Z}_{n}, and the messages that user n𝑛n has received from other users. We denote the corresponding encoding function by φn(L)subscriptsuperscript𝜑𝐿𝑛\varphi^{(L)}_{n}. Let 𝒰ssubscript𝒰s\mathcal{U}_{\text{s}} refer to a subset of users selected by the server, and their local updates are used for aggregation. Let 𝒳𝒮={𝐗n(L)}n∈𝒮subscript𝒳𝒮subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐗𝑛𝐿𝑛𝒮\mathcal{X}_{\mathcal{S}}=\{\mathbf{X}_{n}^{(L)}\}_{n\in\mathcal{S}} represent the set of messages the server receives from a subset of users 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}. The received messages from the users are decoded by the server using the decoding function ψ(L)superscript𝜓𝐿\psi^{(L)}. Function Ω:(𝔽∗)|𝒮|→𝔽L:Ω→superscriptsuperscript𝔽𝒮superscript𝔽𝐿\Omega:(\mathbb{F}^{*})^{|{\mathcal{S}}|}\to\mathbb{F}^{L} represents both the aggregation rule and the user selection method utilized by the server as the outlier detection method. The server updates the global model by applying function ΩΩ\Omega to the decoded received messages, as

𝐰g(t+1)=𝐰g(t)−δt​Λ−1​(Ω​(ψ(L)​(𝐗n(L),n∈𝒮))),superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑡subscript𝛿𝑡superscriptΛ1Ωsuperscript𝜓𝐿superscriptsubscript𝐗𝑛𝐿𝑛𝒮\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{g}^{(t+1)}=\mathbf{w}_{g}^{(t)}-\delta_{t}\Lambda^{-1}\bigg{(}\Omega\big{(}\psi^{(L)}(\mathbf{X}_{n}^{(L)},n\in\mathcal{S})\big{)}\bigg{)},

where δtsubscript𝛿𝑡\delta_{t} is the learning rate at round t𝑡t and Λ−1:𝔽→ℝ:superscriptΛ1→𝔽ℝ\Lambda^{-1}:\mathbb{F}\to\mathbb{R} is a demapping function.

In this setting, we assume that a subset of users 𝒟⊂[N]𝒟delimited-[]𝑁\mathcal{D}\subset[N] drops out, i.e., stay silent (or send ⟂perpendicular-to\perp to other users and the server) during the protocol execution. We denote the maximum number of dropped-out users as D∈ℕ𝐷ℕD\in\mathbb{N}. We also assume that some of the users collude to gain information about the local updates of the honest users. The maximum number of colluding users is denoted by T∈ℕ𝑇ℕT\in\mathbb{N}.
Furthermore, we also assume some of the users are Byzantine adversaries, who engage in adversarial behaviors of two different types: (Type 1) The adversaries may aim to prevent the global model to converge and choose malicious local update parameters, i.e., poisoning attacks (Type 2) the adversaries may send messages to other nodes, inconsistent with the protocol. The maximum number of Byzantine adversaries in the system is denoted by A∈ℕ𝐴ℕA\in\mathbb{N}. We consider that all Byzantine adversaries are probabilistic polynomial time (PPT) algorithms with respect to a security parameter κ∈ℕ𝜅ℕ\kappa\in\mathbb{N} [28]. It means that the Byzantine adversaries can run an algorithm within polynomial time and uses probabilistic methods to try to break the security of the system with a given security parameter κ𝜅\kappa. Note that the identities of dropouts, colluding users, and Byzantine adversaries are not known beforehand.

In addition, to enable verification of the messages in this adversarial system to protect against type 2 error, we use a vector commitment scheme. A vector commitment scheme is a cryptographic primitive that enables a user to commit to a vector with the following desirable features. It is computationally infeasible to determine the committed vector from the commitment value. It is also computationally infeasible to find a different vector that maps to the same commitment value. More precisely, vector commitment scheme VC=(Setup,Commit,Witness,Verify) includes the following components:

  • •

    Setup: 1κ→(pp,sp)→superscript1𝜅ppsp1^{\kappa}\to(\textsf{pp},\textsf{sp}): this protocol is run by a trusted or distributed authority at the beginning to take security parameter κ𝜅\kappa and generates some public parameters (pp) and some local secret parameters (sp).

  • •

    Commit:(pp,𝝂)→C→pp𝝂𝐶(\textsf{pp},\bm{\nu})\to C: this algorithm takes vector 𝝂𝝂\bm{\nu} as input and outputs a commitment C𝐶C.

  • •

    Witness: (pp,𝝂)→𝝎→pp𝝂𝝎(\textsf{pp},\bm{\nu})\to{\bm{\omega}}: this algorithm takes vector 𝝂𝝂\bm{\nu} as input and computes a witness 𝝎𝝎\bm{\omega}.

  • •

    Verify:(pp,C,𝝎)→b∈{True,False}→pp𝐶𝝎𝑏True,False(\textsf{pp},C,\bm{\omega})\to b\in\{\texttt{True,False}\}: this algorithm takes a witness 𝝎𝝎\bm{\omega} and a commitment C𝐶C as input and returns either True or False based on the validity of the witness.

A Byzantine-robust secure aggregation scheme consists of the encoding functions ϕn→n′(L)subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϕ𝐿→𝑛superscript𝑛′\phi^{(L)}_{n\to n^{\prime}}, φn(L)subscriptsuperscript𝜑𝐿𝑛\varphi^{(L)}_{n}, n,n′∈[N]𝑛superscript𝑛′delimited-[]𝑁n,n^{\prime}\in[N], the decoding function ψ(L)superscript𝜓𝐿\psi^{(L)}, the aggregation rule ΩΩ\Omega, and the vector commitment scheme VC such that the following conditions are satisfied:

1. Correctness:

    Correctness of Commitments: For an honest user n𝑛n with quantized local update 𝐰¯nsubscript¯𝐰𝑛\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n} of data and a commitment Cn=Commit​(pp,𝐰¯n)subscript𝐶𝑛Commitppsubscript¯𝐰𝑛C_{n}=\textsf{Commit}(\textsf{pp},\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n}), the created witness 𝝎n=Witness​(pp,𝐰¯)subscript𝝎𝑛Witnesspp¯𝐰\bm{\omega}_{n}=\textsf{Witness}(\textsf{pp},\bar{\mathbf{w}}) successfully satisfies Verify​(pp,Cn,𝝎n)=TrueVerifyppsubscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝝎𝑛True\textsf{Verify}(\textsf{pp},C_{n},\bm{\omega}_{n})=\texttt{True}.

  • •

    Correctness of the Final Result: Despite the presence of at most D𝐷D dropouts, A𝐴A Byzantine adversaries, and T𝑇T colluding users, the server maintains the capability to recover 𝐰¯≜1|𝒰s|​∑n∈𝒰s𝐰¯n≜¯𝐰1subscript𝒰ssubscript𝑛subscript𝒰ssubscript¯𝐰𝑛\bar{\mathbf{w}}\triangleq~{}\frac{1}{|\mathcal{U}_{\text{s}}|}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{U}_{\text{s}}}{\bar{\mathbf{w}}}_{n} which must be the outcome of Ω​(ψ(L)​(𝐗n(L),n∈𝒮))Ωsuperscript𝜓𝐿superscriptsubscript𝐗𝑛𝐿𝑛𝒮\Omega\big{(}\psi^{(L)}(\mathbf{X}_{n}^{(L)},n\in\mathcal{S})\big{)}.

2. Robustness against Byzantine Adversaries:

  • •

    Commitment Binding: The algorithm Commit should create a binding and deterministic commitment to the data. Formally, for adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} who can simulate any user, it must hold

    Pr((\displaystyle\text{Pr}\bigg{(}( pp,sp)←Setup(1κ),(𝝂,𝝂′)←𝒜(pp,sp):\displaystyle\textsf{pp},\textsf{sp})\leftarrow\textsf{Setup}(1^{\kappa}),(\bm{\nu},\bm{\nu}^{\prime})\leftarrow\mathcal{A}(\textsf{pp},\textsf{sp}):
    𝝂≠𝝂′∧Commit(𝝂)=Commit(𝝂′))≤ϵ(κ),\displaystyle\bm{\nu}\neq\bm{\nu}^{\prime}\wedge\textsf{Commit}(\bm{\nu})=\textsf{Commit}(\bm{\nu}^{\prime})\bigg{)}\leq\epsilon(\kappa),

    where function ϵ(.)\epsilon(.) is a negligible function, which means for all c>0𝑐0c>0 there exists a kcsubscript𝑘𝑐k_{c} such that for all k>kc𝑘subscript𝑘𝑐k>k_{c} we have ϵ​(k)<1kcitalic-ϵ𝑘1superscript𝑘𝑐\epsilon(k)<\frac{1}{k^{c}}. In short, this means that a Byzantine adversary committer can present two distinct values of ν𝜈\nu with the same commitment C𝐶C with vanishing probability.

  • •

    Global Model Resiliency: The aggregation rule ΩΩ\Omega should prioritize global model resiliency, even in the presence of up to A𝐴A Byzantine adversaries (type 1), by ensuring that at the end of each iteration, the output of the aggregation rule remains close to the true gradient. Formally, at each iteration of the training process, for the true gradient vector 𝐠≜∇𝔏​(𝐰g(t))≜𝐠∇𝔏superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑡\mathbf{g}\triangleq\nabla\mathfrak{L}(\mathbf{w}_{g}^{(t)}), the output of the aggregation rule, i.e., 𝐠GAR≜Ω​(ψ(L)​(𝐗n(L),n∈𝒮))≜subscript𝐠GARΩsuperscript𝜓𝐿superscriptsubscript𝐗𝑛𝐿𝑛𝒮\mathbf{g}_{\text{GAR}}\triangleq\Omega\big{(}\psi^{(L)}(\mathbf{X}_{n}^{(L)},n\in\mathcal{S})\big{)} must satisfy a well-defined closeness criterion ξ​(𝐠GAR,𝐠,N,A)𝜉subscript𝐠GAR𝐠𝑁𝐴\xi(\mathbf{g}_{\text{GAR}},\mathbf{g},N,A).

  • •

    Malicious Computation Results: The general scheme should maintain robustness against any malicious computation results produced by Byzantine adversaries (type 2) that may be sent to the server and other users during each step of the scheme.

3. Privacy Constraint:

  • •

    Hiding Property: If a proof (pp,Cn)ppsubscript𝐶𝑛(\textsf{pp},C_{n}) and a witness 𝝎nsubscript𝝎𝑛\bm{\omega}_{n} for quantized local update 𝐰¯nsubscript¯𝐰𝑛\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n}, n∈[N]𝑛delimited-[]𝑁n\in[N] are given and the verification Verify(pp,Cnsubscript𝐶𝑛C_{n},𝝎nsubscript𝝎𝑛\bm{\omega}_{n}) returns True, no user can figure out the value of 𝐰¯nsubscript¯𝐰𝑛\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n} with non-negligible probability.

  • •

    Privacy of Individual Local Updates: The privacy constraint ensures that no group of up to T𝑇T colluding users can extract any information about the local models of other honest users. In addition, after receiving 𝒳𝒮subscript𝒳𝒮\mathcal{X}_{\mathcal{S}} and colluding with up to T𝑇T colluding users, the server should not gain any information about local updates of the honest users, beyond the aggregation of them, and beyond what is strictly required by the user selection (outlier detection) method.

For a Byzantine-robust secure aggregation scheme satisfying the above conditions, we define average per-user communication load and the server communication load as follows:

where H​(X)𝐻𝑋H(X) refer to the entropy of random variable X𝑋X. Here, it represents the number of symbols (bits) required to transmit the messages.

Definition 2 (Server communication load).

denoted by Rserversubscript𝑅serverR_{\text{server}}, is defined as the aggregated size of all messages received by the server, i.e.,

Rserver=∑n∈[N]H​(𝐗n(L)).subscript𝑅serversubscript𝑛delimited-[]𝑁𝐻subscriptsuperscript𝐗𝐿𝑛\displaystyle R_{\text{server}}=\sum_{n\in[N]}H(\mathbf{X}^{(L)}_{n}).

In this paper, we propose ByzSecAgg, a novel single-server Byzantine-robust secure aggregation scheme to meet the aforementioned conditions. In ByzSecAgg, each user partitions its local update vector of length L𝐿L into K𝐾K smaller sub-vectors of length LK𝐿𝐾\frac{L}{K} and broadcasts constant-size commitments of them. Users then use ramp sharing [29] to share the sub-vectors with others, which can be verified using the commitments. This method allows for a major reduction in communication loads, however, it makes computing the pairwise distances between the local updates and removing the outliers challenging. To address this issue, we use techniques inspired by coded computing [30, 31, 32], where each user runs another ramp sharing, where data vectors are embedded in the coefficients differently. These two sets of shares admit the computation of the pairwise distances in a very efficient way. The server then receives the pairwise distances of the shares, which are used to recover the pairwise distances of the local updates. These distances are used in the multi-Krum algorithm [18], as the outlier detection method, to select m𝑚m users for aggregation. Finally, communication with the server is required so that the server can obtain the aggregation of local updates of the selected users. To be able to verify that users follow the sharing protocol correctly and also not change their data in the second round of sharing, we need to be able to verify it against some commitment. We suggest using some linear commitment scheme [33] that unlike many existing solutions, the size of the commitment remains constant and does not grow with the size of data.

III Preliminaries

In order to develop a secure aggregation scheme that is resilient to Byzantine adversarial behavior, particularly of type 1, it is essential to employ a robust aggregation method. Specifically, in this paper, we leverage the multi-Krum algorithm proposed in [18]. More in general, any alternative aggregation methods that are robust against type 1 adversarial attacks can also be employed in ByzSecAgg.

III-A Multi-Krum Algorithm

In the distributed stochastic gradient descent (SGD) problem, and in the presence of Byzantine adversaries (type 1), using the average of all users’ gradients to update the model parameters is not robust since a single Byzantine user can cause an arbitrarily large error in the update. To handle this, the server must use a gradient aggregation rule (GAR) ΩΩ\Omega that is resistant to malicious gradients that may be produced by up to A𝐴A Byzantine adversaries. At iteration t𝑡t, assume that each honest user n𝑛n calculates an estimate 𝐰n(t)=𝐆​(𝐰g(t),ζn(t))superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑛𝑡𝐆superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑛𝑡\mathbf{w}_{n}^{(t)}=\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{w}_{g}^{(t)},\zeta_{n}^{(t)}) of the gradient of the cost function 𝔏𝔏\mathfrak{L}, where ζn(t)superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑛𝑡\zeta_{n}^{(t)} is a random variable representing the sample or mini-batch of samples drawn from user n𝑛n’s dataset, and 𝐰g(t)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑡\mathbf{w}_{g}^{(t)} is the global model parameter received from the server. On the other hand, Byzantine adversarial users may send some arbitrary vector to the server (type 1 adversarial attack). One method to measure resilience against such Byzantine users is through the concept of (γ,A)𝛾𝐴(\gamma,A)-Byzantine resilience, as introduced and supported by convergence theories in [18].

Definition 3 ((γ,A)𝛾𝐴(\gamma,A)-Byzantine Resilience [18]).

Consider N𝑁N vectors 𝐰1,…,𝐰N∈ℝLsubscript𝐰1…subscript𝐰𝑁superscriptℝ𝐿\mathbf{w}_{1},\dots,\mathbf{w}_{N}\in\mathbb{R}^{L} which are gradient vectors received by the server from N𝑁N users. If user i𝑖i is non-Byzantine, then 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i} is independent identically distributed random vector, 𝐰i∼𝐆​(𝐰g(t),ζi(t))similar-tosubscript𝐰𝑖𝐆superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}_{i}\sim\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{w}_{g}^{(t)},\zeta_{i}^{(t)}), with 𝔼ζi(t)​𝐆=∇𝔏​(𝐰g(t))subscript𝔼superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑖𝑡𝐆∇𝔏superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑡\mathbb{E}_{\zeta_{i}^{(t)}}{\mathbf{G}}=\nabla\mathfrak{L}(\mathbf{w}_{g}^{(t)}). Vector 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i} for a Byzantine user can be any arbitrary vector. For any angular value 0≤γ<π/20𝛾𝜋20\leq\gamma<\pi/2 and any integer 0≤A≤N0𝐴𝑁0\leq A\leq N denoting the maximum number of Byzantine adversaries, a gradient aggregation rule (GAR) ΩΩ\Omega is called (γ,A)𝛾𝐴(\gamma,A)-Byzantine resilient if vector 𝐰GAR≜Ω​(𝐰1,…,𝐰N)≜subscript𝐰GARΩsubscript𝐰1…subscript𝐰𝑁\mathbf{w}_{\text{GAR}}\triangleq\Omega(\mathbf{w}_{1},\dots,\mathbf{w}_{N}) satisfies the following two conditions:

  1. 1.

    ⟨𝔼​[𝐰GAR],𝐠⟩≥(1−sin⁡γ)​∥𝐠∥2>0𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐰GAR𝐠1𝛾superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐠20\langle\mathbb{E}[{\mathbf{w}_{\text{GAR}}}],\mathbf{g}\rangle\geq(1-\sin\gamma)\lVert{\mathbf{g}}\rVert^{2}>0, where 𝐠𝐠\mathbf{g} is the true gradient 𝐠≜∇𝔏​(𝐰g(t))≜𝐠∇𝔏superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑡\mathbf{g}\triangleq\nabla\mathfrak{L}(\mathbf{w}_{g}^{(t)}).

  2. 2.

    For r∈{2,3,4}𝑟234r\in\{2,3,4\}, 𝔼​[∥𝐰GAR∥r]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰GAR𝑟\mathbb{E}[\lVert{\mathbf{w}_{\text{GAR}}}\rVert^{r}] is upper bounded by 𝔼​[∥𝐰GAR∥r]≤c​∑r1+⋯+rk=r𝔼​[∥𝐆∥r1]​…​𝔼​[∥𝐆∥rk]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰GAR𝑟𝑐subscriptsubscript𝑟1⋯subscript𝑟𝑘𝑟𝔼delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐆subscript𝑟1…𝔼delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐆subscript𝑟𝑘\mathbb{E}[\lVert{\mathbf{w}_{\text{GAR}}}\rVert^{r}]\leq c\sum\limits_{r_{1}+\dots+r_{k}=r}\mathbb{E}[\lVert{\mathbf{G}}\rVert^{r_{1}}]\dots\mathbb{E}[\lVert{\mathbf{G}}\rVert^{r_{k}}], where c𝑐c is a generic constant and r1,…,rksubscript𝑟1…subscript𝑟𝑘r_{1},\dots,r_{k} are non-negative integers.

In this definition, Condition 1 ensures that the angle between the true gradient 𝐠𝐠\mathbf{g} and the output 𝐰GARsubscript𝐰GAR\mathbf{w}_{\text{GAR}} is small enough and on average the output is in the same direction as the true gradient. Condition 2 ensures that the second, third, and fourth-order moments of the output of the gradient aggregation rule are bounded by a linear combination of the moments of a correct estimator of the gradient. This is generally necessary to ensure the convergence of the SGD algorithm.

Krum algorithm [18] is a gradient aggregation rule which is resilient to the presence of A𝐴A Byzantine adversaries users in a distributed system consisting of N𝑁N users as long as N>2​A+2𝑁2𝐴2N>2A+2. The Krum aggregation algorithm returns the gradient computed by the user with the lowest score, which is determined by considering the N−A−2𝑁𝐴2N-A-2 closest gradients to that user’s gradient. More precisely, let 𝐰1,…,𝐰Nsubscript𝐰1…subscript𝐰𝑁\mathbf{w}_{1},\dots,\mathbf{w}_{N} be the gradients received by the server. Krum algorithm assigns to each vector 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i} score s​(i)≜∑j:i→j∥𝐰i−𝐰j∥2≜𝑠𝑖subscript:𝑗→𝑖𝑗superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑖subscript𝐰𝑗2s(i)\triangleq\sum\limits_{j:i\to j}\lVert{\mathbf{w}_{i}-\mathbf{w}_{j}}\rVert^{2}, where i→j→𝑖𝑗i\to j denotes that 𝐰jsubscript𝐰𝑗\mathbf{w}_{j} belongs to the N−A−2𝑁𝐴2N-A-2 closest vector (in terms of squared distance) to 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i} for any i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j. The output of Krum algorithm is KR​(𝐰1,…,𝐰N)=𝐰i∗KRsubscript𝐰1…subscript𝐰𝑁subscript𝐰superscript𝑖\text{KR}(\mathbf{w}_{1},\dots,\mathbf{w}_{N})=\mathbf{w}_{i^{*}}, where i∗superscript𝑖i^{*} is the gradient with the lowest score, i.e., for all i𝑖i we have s​(i∗)≤s​(i)𝑠superscript𝑖𝑠𝑖s(i^{*})\leq s(i).

Lemma 1 ([18]).

Consider i.i.d. random vectors 𝐰1,…,𝐰N∈ℝLsubscript𝐰1…subscript𝐰𝑁superscriptℝ𝐿\mathbf{w}_{1},\dots,\mathbf{w}_{N}\in\mathbb{R}^{L} such that 𝐰i∼𝐆​(𝐰g,ζi)similar-tosubscript𝐰𝑖𝐆subscript𝐰𝑔subscript𝜁𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i}\sim\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{w}_{g},\zeta_{i}), with 𝔼​𝐆​(𝐰g,ζi)=∇𝔏​(𝐰g)𝔼𝐆subscript𝐰𝑔subscript𝜁𝑖∇𝔏subscript𝐰𝑔\mathbb{E}{\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{w}_{g},\zeta_{i})}=\nabla\mathfrak{L}(\mathbf{w}_{g}). Define L​σ2​(𝐰g)≜𝔼​[∥𝐆​(𝐰g,ζi)−∇𝔏​(𝐰g)∥2]≜𝐿superscript𝜎2subscript𝐰𝑔𝔼delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐆subscript𝐰𝑔subscript𝜁𝑖∇𝔏subscript𝐰𝑔2L\sigma^{2}(\mathbf{w}_{g})\triangleq\mathbb{E}[\lVert{\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{w}_{g},\zeta_{i})-\nabla\mathfrak{L}(\mathbf{w}_{g})}\rVert^{2}]. Let 𝐰~1,…,𝐰~Asubscript~𝐰1…subscript~𝐰𝐴\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{1},\dots,\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{A} be any A𝐴A random vectors that may depend on the 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i}’s. If N>2​A+2𝑁2𝐴2N>2A+2 and η​(N,A)​L​σ<∥∇𝔏​(𝐰g)∥𝜂𝑁𝐴𝐿𝜎delimited-∥∥∇𝔏subscript𝐰𝑔\eta(N,A)\sqrt{L}\sigma<\lVert{\nabla\mathfrak{L}(\mathbf{w}_{g})}\rVert, where η​(N,A)𝜂𝑁𝐴\eta(N,A) is defined as

η​(N,A)≜2​(N−A+A​(N−A−2)+A2​(N−A−1)N−2​A−2),≜𝜂𝑁𝐴2𝑁𝐴𝐴𝑁𝐴2superscript𝐴2𝑁𝐴1𝑁2𝐴2\displaystyle\eta(N,A)\triangleq\sqrt{2\bigg{(}N-A+\frac{A(N-A-2)+A^{2}(N-A-1)}{N-2A-2}\bigg{)}},

then the Krum algorithm is (γ,A)𝛾𝐴(\gamma,A)-Byzantine resilience, where 0≤γ<π20𝛾𝜋20\leq\gamma<\frac{\pi}{2} is defined by sin⁡γ=η​(N,A)​L​σ∥∇𝔏​(𝐰g)∥𝛾𝜂𝑁𝐴𝐿𝜎delimited-∥∥∇𝔏subscript𝐰𝑔\sin\gamma=\frac{{\eta(N,A)\sqrt{L}\sigma}}{\lVert{\nabla\mathfrak{L}(\mathbf{w}_{g})}\rVert}.

The convergence analysis of the SGD using Krum algorithm is presented in [18]. The proof relies on certain conditions regarding the learning rates and the gradient estimator. In addition, in that paper, a strongest variant of Krum algorithm is proposed called multi-Krum. In multi-Krum, m∈[N]𝑚delimited-[]𝑁m\in[N], m<N−2​A−2𝑚𝑁2𝐴2m<N-2A-2, gradient vectors 𝐰i1∗,…,𝐰im∗subscript𝐰subscriptsuperscript𝑖1…subscript𝐰subscriptsuperscript𝑖𝑚\mathbf{w}_{i^{*}_{1}},\dots,\mathbf{w}_{i^{*}_{m}} are selected that have the lowest scores and the output of the algorithm is the average of the selected vectors, i.e., 1m​∑k=1m𝐰ik∗1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑚subscript𝐰subscriptsuperscript𝑖𝑘\frac{1}{m}\sum_{k=1}^{m}\mathbf{w}_{i^{*}_{k}}.

The main goal of ByzSecAgg is to design a scheme that is efficient in terms of communication loads and ensures the privacy conditions, despite the presence of Byzantine users with adversarial behavior (type 1 and type 2), colluding users, and dropouts.

IV The Proposed Scheme

In this section, we explain ByzSecAgg in details. Consider a federated learning system with one server and N𝑁N users. The scheme is designed to handle a maximum number of T𝑇T colluding users, a maximum number of D𝐷D dropout users, and a maximum number of A𝐴A Byzantine users, as defined in Section II. The adversaries are assumed to be probabilistic polynomial time (PPT) algorithms with respect to the security parameter κ𝜅\kappa. The set of colluding users, dropouts, and adversaries are not known beforehand.

User n𝑛n has a local update 𝐰n∈ℝLsubscript𝐰𝑛superscriptℝ𝐿\mathbf{w}_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{L}. We focus on perfect secure aggregation schemes, which rely on operations in a finite field to protect the privacy of the local updates [12, 14, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 13]. We choose a finite field, G​F​(p)𝐺𝐹𝑝GF(p) denoted by 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p}, for some prime number p𝑝p which is large enough. User n𝑛n samples vectors 𝒵n={𝐳n,j,j∈[T]}subscript𝒵𝑛subscript𝐳𝑛𝑗𝑗delimited-[]𝑇{\mathcal{Z}}_{n}=\{{\mathbf{z}}_{n,j},j\in[T]\} and 𝒵~n={𝐳¯n,j,j∈[T]}subscript~𝒵𝑛subscript¯𝐳𝑛𝑗𝑗delimited-[]𝑇\tilde{\mathcal{Z}}_{n}=\{{\bar{\mathbf{z}}}_{n,j},j\in[T]\} uniformly at random from 𝔽pLKsubscriptsuperscript𝔽𝐿𝐾𝑝{\mathbb{F}}^{\frac{L}{K}}_{p}, for some parameter K∈ℕ𝐾ℕK\in\mathbb{N}. In addition, user n𝑛n samples random scalars ℛn={rn,i(j),i∈[2(K+T)−1]\{K},j∈[N]}{{\mathcal{R}}}_{n}=\{{r}^{(j)}_{n,i},i\in[2(K+T)-1]\backslash\{K\},j\in[N]\} uniformly at random from 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝{\mathbb{F}}_{p}.
Each user takes the following steps:

  1. 1.

    Quantization: User n𝑛n converts its local update vector 𝐰n∈ℝLsubscript𝐰𝑛superscriptℝ𝐿\mathbf{w}_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{L} in real numbers to vector 𝐰¯n∈𝔽pLsubscript¯𝐰𝑛superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑝𝐿\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n}\in\mathbb{F}_{p}^{L} in finite field. This conversion allows for the use of finite field operations, which play a crucial role in protecting the privacy of the local updates. To achieve this, each user first applies the stochastic rounding function in [34, 24] element-wise as follows

    Qq​(x)={⌊q​x⌋qwith probability ​1−(q​x−⌊q​x⌋),⌊q​x⌋+1qwith probability ​q​x−⌊q​x⌋,subscript𝑄𝑞𝑥cases𝑞𝑥𝑞with probability 1𝑞𝑥𝑞𝑥𝑞𝑥1𝑞with probability 𝑞𝑥𝑞𝑥\displaystyle Q_{q}(x)=\begin{cases}\frac{\lfloor qx\rfloor}{q}&\text{with probability }1-(qx-\lfloor qx\rfloor),\\ \frac{\lfloor qx\rfloor+1}{q}&\text{with probability }qx-\lfloor qx\rfloor,\end{cases} (1)

    where integer q≥1𝑞1q\geq 1 is the number of quantization levels and ⌊x⌋𝑥\lfloor x\rfloor is the largest integer that is less than or equal to x𝑥x. Note that the rounding function is unbiased, i.e., 𝔼​[Qq​(x)]=x𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑄𝑞𝑥𝑥\mathbb{E}[Q_{q}(x)]=x. In addition, to represent negative values in the finite field, a mapping function is needed. The quantized version of the local update of user n𝑛n denoted by 𝐰¯nsubscript¯𝐰𝑛\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n} is defined as follows

    𝐰¯n≜Λ​(q​Qq​(𝐰n)),≜subscript¯𝐰𝑛Λ𝑞subscript𝑄𝑞subscript𝐰𝑛\displaystyle\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n}\triangleq\Lambda{\bigg{(}qQ_{q}(\mathbf{w}_{n})\bigg{)}}, (2)

    where Λ:ℝ→𝔽p:Λ→ℝsubscript𝔽𝑝\Lambda:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{F}_{p} is a mapping function which is applied element-wise and defined as

    Λ​(x)={xif ​x≥0,x+pif ​x<0.Λ𝑥cases𝑥if 𝑥0𝑥𝑝if 𝑥0\displaystyle\Lambda(x)=\begin{cases}x&\text{if }x\geq 0,\\ x+p&\text{if }x<0.\end{cases} (3)

    It should be noted that in this step, any rounding function that ensures the convergence of the model can be utilized. There are no restrictions on selecting the rounding function in the proposed method.

  2. 2.

    Partitioning the local updates: User n𝑛n partitions its quantized local update 𝐰¯nsubscript¯𝐰𝑛\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n} into K∈ℤ𝐾ℤK\in\mathbb{Z} sub-vectors, i.e.,

    𝐰¯n=[𝐰¯n,1,𝐰¯n,2,…,𝐰¯n,K]T,subscript¯𝐰𝑛superscriptsubscript¯𝐰𝑛1subscript¯𝐰𝑛2…subscript¯𝐰𝑛𝐾𝑇\displaystyle\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n}=[\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n,1},\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n,2},\dots,\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n,K}]^{T},

    where each part 𝐰¯n,k,k∈[K]subscript¯𝐰𝑛𝑘𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n,k},k\in[K] is a vector of size LK𝐿𝐾\frac{L}{K} and K∈[1:(N−D+1)2−A−T]K\in[1:\frac{(N-D+1)}{2}-A-T]. If the value of K𝐾K does not divide L𝐿L, we can zero-pad the quantized local models.

  3. 3.

    Broadcasting the Commitments: Since all steps are done in the presence of adversarial behavior of type 2, some initial hiding commitments are needed. This enables each user to commit to certain values without revealing any information about those values. Using the commitments, each user can verify that the messages being received are effectively the ones for which the commitment was created and ensure that all users follow the protocol honestly. Inspired by the commitment scheme in [33], we consider a scheme where each user n𝑛n produces the commitments as follows

    Ci(n)={∏j=1LK(gβj−1)[𝐰¯n,i]j,if ​i∈[K],∏j=1LK(gβj−1)[𝐳n,i−K]j,if i∈[K+1:K+T],∏j=1LK(gβj−1)[𝐳~n,i−K−T]j,if i∈[K+T+1:K+2T],∏j=1N(gβj−1)rn,i−K−2​T(j),if i∈[K+2T+1:3K+4T−1]i≠2​K+2​T,\displaystyle{C}_{i}^{(n)}=\begin{cases}\prod\limits_{j=1}^{\frac{L}{K}}(g^{\beta^{j-1}})^{[\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n,i}]_{j}},&\text{if }i\in[K],\\ \prod\limits_{j=1}^{\frac{L}{K}}(g^{\beta^{j-1}})^{[\mathbf{z}_{n,i-K}]_{j}},&\text{if }i\in[K+1:K+T],\\ \prod\limits_{j=1}^{\frac{L}{K}}(g^{\beta^{j-1}})^{[\tilde{\mathbf{z}}_{n,i-K-T}]_{j}},&\text{if }i\in[K+T+1:K+2T],\\ \prod\limits_{j=1}^{N}(g^{\beta^{j-1}})^{r_{n,i-K-2T}^{(j)}},&\begin{subarray}{c}\text{if }i\in[K+2T+1:3K+4T-1]\\ i\neq 2K+2T\end{subarray},\end{cases} (4)

    where [𝐰¯n,i]jsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript¯𝐰𝑛𝑖𝑗{[\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n,i}]_{j}} is the j𝑗j-th entry of 𝐰¯n,isubscript¯𝐰𝑛𝑖\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n,i}, and g𝑔g is a generator of cyclic group 𝔾𝔾\mathbb{G} with product operation, of prime order p≥22​κ𝑝superscript22𝜅p\geq 2^{2\kappa}. In addition, β∈𝔽p𝛽subscript𝔽𝑝\beta\in\mathbb{F}_{p} is a secret parameter generated by a trusted authority. The trusted authority then generates public parameters (gβ0,gβ1,…,gβmax⁡(LK,N)−1)superscript𝑔superscript𝛽0superscript𝑔superscript𝛽1…superscript𝑔superscript𝛽𝐿𝐾𝑁1(g^{\beta^{0}},g^{\beta^{1}},\dots,g^{\beta^{\max{(\frac{L}{K},N)-1}}}). Recall that the size of each commitment is equal to a single group element. These commitments are binding, and computationally hiding under the assumption that the discrete logarithm problem is hard in 𝔾𝔾\mathbb{G} (see proofs in Subsection V).

  4. 4.

    Secret Sharing (First Round): User n𝑛n forms the following polynomial function.

    𝐅n​(x)=∑k=1K𝐰¯n,k​xk−1+∑t=1T𝐳n,t​xK+t−1,subscript𝐅𝑛𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript¯𝐰𝑛𝑘superscript𝑥𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝐳𝑛𝑡superscript𝑥𝐾𝑡1\displaystyle\mathbf{F}_{n}(x)=\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n,k}x^{k-1}+\sum\limits_{t=1}^{T}\mathbf{z}_{n,t}x^{K+t-1}, (5)

    where the coefficient of K𝐾K first terms are the partitions of 𝐰¯n,ksubscript¯𝐰𝑛𝑘\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n,k}, for k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K]. Each user n𝑛n uses its polynomial function 𝐅n(.)\mathbf{F}_{n}(.) to securely share its local update with other users. Let {αi∈𝔽p:i∈[N]}conditional-setsubscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝔽𝑝𝑖delimited-[]𝑁\{\alpha_{i}\in\mathbb{F}_{p}:i\in[N]\} be a set of N𝑁N distinct non-zero values in 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p}. This set is revealed to all users, such that each user n𝑛n sends one valuation of its created polynomial function at αn~subscript𝛼~𝑛\alpha_{\tilde{n}} to user n~~𝑛\tilde{n}, for n~∈[N]~𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\tilde{n}\in[N]. In particular, user n𝑛n sends vector 𝐬n,n~≜𝐅n​(αn~)≜subscript𝐬𝑛~𝑛subscript𝐅𝑛subscript𝛼~𝑛\mathbf{s}_{n,\tilde{n}}\triangleq\mathbf{F}_{n}(\alpha_{\tilde{n}}) to user n~~𝑛{\tilde{n}}, and each vector has a size of LK𝐿𝐾\frac{L}{K}. In this step, if a user m𝑚m drops out and stays silent, 𝐅m(.)\mathbf{F}_{m}(.) are just presumed to be zero. Since the proposed secret sharing is based on ramp sharing scheme, the local update is kept private against T𝑇T colluding users by adding T𝑇T independent random vectors in (5) to the message [29, 14].

  5. 5.

    Verification (First Round): Having received the shares 𝐬n~,nsubscript𝐬~𝑛𝑛\mathbf{s}_{\tilde{n},n} from users n~∈[N]~𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\tilde{n}\in[N], user n𝑛n can verify them.   9. 9.

    Distance Recovery at the Server: Since d¯i,j​(x)subscript¯𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑥\bar{d}_{i,j}(x) is a polynomial function of degree 2​(K+T−1)2𝐾𝑇12(K+T-1), the server can use Reed-Solomon decoding [35] to recover all the coefficients of this polynomial using 2​(K+T)−12𝐾𝑇12(K+T)-1 evaluations of d¯i,j​(x)subscript¯𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑥\bar{d}_{i,j}(x). Since in the setting, there are at most A𝐴A adversarial users (type 2), d¯i,j​(x)subscript¯𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑥\bar{d}_{i,j}(x) can only be correctly recovered if the server receives at least 2​(K+T+A)−12𝐾𝑇𝐴12(K+T+A)-1 outcomes from the users. In addition, d¯i,j(n)superscriptsubscript¯𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑛\bar{d}_{i,j}^{(n)}, for that are sent to the server from the non-adversarial users n∈[N]\𝒟𝑛\delimited-[]𝑁𝒟n\in[N]\backslash\mathcal{D} are indeed equal to d¯i,j​(αn)subscript¯𝑑𝑖𝑗subscript𝛼𝑛\bar{d}_{i,j}(\alpha_{n}), for i<j∈[N]𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑁i<j\in[N]. Therefore, the server is able to recover d¯i,j​(x)subscript¯𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑥\bar{d}_{i,j}(x). The coefficient of xK−1superscript𝑥𝐾1x^{K-1} in d¯i,j​(x)subscript¯𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑥\bar{d}_{i,j}(x) is equal to aK−1;i,j=∥𝐰¯i−𝐰¯j∥2subscript𝑎𝐾1𝑖𝑗superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript¯𝐰𝑖subscript¯𝐰𝑗2a_{K-1;i,j}=\lVert{\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{i}-\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{j}}\rVert^{2} that the server looks for in order to find the outliers. According to (10), the remaining recovered coefficients of d¯i,j​(x)subscript¯𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑥\bar{d}_{i,j}(x) are distorted by noise and do not disclose any additional details about the local updates apart from the targeted pairwise distance sought by the server.

    Then the server converts the calculated distances from the finite field to the real domain as follows.

    di,j=Λ−1​(aK−1;i,j)q2,subscript𝑑𝑖𝑗superscriptΛ1subscript𝑎𝐾1𝑖𝑗superscript𝑞2\displaystyle d_{i,j}=\frac{\Lambda^{-1}(a_{K-1;i,j})}{q^{2}}, (12)

    where Λ−1:𝔽p→ℝ:superscriptΛ1→subscript𝔽𝑝ℝ\Lambda^{-1}:\mathbb{F}_{p}\to\mathbb{R} is a demapping function which is applied element-wise and is defined as

    Λ−1​(x¯)={x¯if ​0≤x¯<p−12,x¯−pif ​p−12≤x¯<p.superscriptΛ1¯𝑥cases¯𝑥if 0¯𝑥𝑝12¯𝑥𝑝if 𝑝12¯𝑥𝑝\displaystyle\Lambda^{-1}(\bar{x})=\begin{cases}\bar{x}&\text{if }0\leq\bar{x}<\frac{p-1}{2},\\ \bar{x}-p&\text{if }\frac{p-1}{2}\leq\bar{x}<p.\end{cases} (13)

    Assuming a sufficiently large field size p𝑝p, we can guarantee the accurate recovery of pair-wise distances.

  10. 10.

    Outlier Detection at the Server: A distance-based outlier detection method (or a closeness criterion) can be employed to make sure that the local updates selected by the server are consistent with each other. This will help to eliminate any local updates that are significantly different from the others (adversarial behavior of type 1) and may not be suitable for inclusion in the update. In this scheme, multi-Krum algorithm (see [18] and Subsection III-A) is utilized for this purpose. Upon completion of the algorithm, the server selects a group of m𝑚m users whose local updates are close to each other and broadcasts a list of the chosen users, denoted by 𝒰s⊂[N]subscript𝒰sdelimited-[]𝑁\mathcal{U}_{\text{s}}\subset[N]. As stated in [18], the multi-Krum algorithm ensures the resiliency of the global model, as defined in Section II, and the convergence of the sequence of gradients (See Subsection V).

  11. 11.

    Aggregation of the Shares: Each user calculates the aggregation of shares of users belong to set 𝒰ssubscript𝒰s\mathcal{U}_{\text{s}}, i.e., 𝐬n=∑n~∈𝒰s𝐅n~​(αn)subscript𝐬𝑛subscript~𝑛subscript𝒰ssubscript𝐅~𝑛subscript𝛼𝑛\mathbf{s}_{n}~{}=~{}\sum_{\tilde{n}\in\mathcal{U}_{\text{s}}}\mathbf{F}_{\tilde{n}}(\alpha_{n}), and sends it to the server. In this step, each user sends a vector of size LK𝐿𝐾\frac{L}{K} to the server.

  12. 12.

    Recovering the Aggregation: Let us define

    𝐅​(x)≜≜𝐅𝑥absent\displaystyle\mathbf{F}(x)\triangleq ∑n∈𝒰s𝐅n​(x)=∑k=1Kxk−1​∑n∈𝒰s𝐰¯n,ksubscript𝑛subscript𝒰ssubscript𝐅𝑛𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscript𝑥𝑘1subscript𝑛subscript𝒰ssubscript¯𝐰𝑛𝑘\displaystyle\sum_{n\in\mathcal{U}_{\text{s}}}\mathbf{F}_{n}(x)=\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}x^{k-1}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{U}_{\text{s}}}\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n,k} (14)
    +∑t=1TxK+t−1​∑n∈𝒰s𝐳n,t,superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript𝑥𝐾𝑡1subscript𝑛subscript𝒰ssubscript𝐳𝑛𝑡\displaystyle+\sum\limits_{t=1}^{T}x^{K+t-1}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{U}_{\text{s}}}\mathbf{z}_{n,t},

    as a polynomial of degree K+T−1𝐾𝑇1K+T-1. Let 𝒳𝒮≜{𝐬n}n∈𝒮≜subscript𝒳𝒮subscriptsubscript𝐬𝑛𝑛𝒮\mathcal{X}_{\mathcal{S}}\triangleq\{\mathbf{s}_{n}\}_{n\in\mathcal{S}} denote the set of messages received by the server, where 𝒮=[N]\𝒟𝒮\delimited-[]𝑁𝒟\mathcal{S}=[N]\backslash\mathcal{D}. We note that 𝐬nsubscript𝐬𝑛\mathbf{s}_{n}, for non-Byzantine users, is the evaluation of 𝐅​(x)𝐅𝑥\mathbf{F}(x) at αnsubscript𝛼𝑛\alpha_{n}. Thus, if the server receives a minimum of K+T+2​A𝐾𝑇2𝐴K+T+2A results from the users, it can accurately recover the polynomial function 𝐅​(x)𝐅𝑥\mathbf{F}(x) using Reed-Solomon decoding. In this decoding process, the first K𝐾K terms correspond to the partitions of 𝐰¯=∑n∈𝒰s𝐰¯n¯𝐰subscript𝑛subscript𝒰ssubscript¯𝐰𝑛\bar{\mathbf{w}}=\sum_{n\in\mathcal{U}_{\text{s}}}\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n}. To ensure successful aggregation, the field size p𝑝p must be sufficiently large to avoid encountering boundary issues during the process.

    After recovering the aggregate of the users’ local updates, the server updates the global model for the next iteration using the following procedure.

    𝐰g(t+1)=𝐰g(t)−δtq​|𝒰s|​Λ−1​(𝐰¯),subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡1𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑡𝑔subscript𝛿𝑡𝑞subscript𝒰𝑠superscriptΛ1¯𝐰\displaystyle\mathbf{w}^{(t+1)}_{g}=\mathbf{w}^{(t)}_{g}-\frac{\delta_{t}}{q|\mathcal{U}_{s}|}\Lambda^{-1}\big{(}\bar{\mathbf{w}}\big{)}, (15)

    where demapping function Λ−1(.)\Lambda^{-1}(.) is defined in (13), and δtsubscript𝛿𝑡\delta_{t} is the learning rate at round t𝑡t.

    Algorithm 1 summarizes ByzSecAgg based on the aforementioned steps.

Remark 1:

The proposed scheme uses some methods to mitigate adversarial behaviors of type 1 and type 2. To protect against adversarial behavior of type 1, where attempts are made to manipulate the global model at the server by altering their local updates, ByzSecAgg employs a distance-based outlier detection mechanism (multi-Krum algorithm). This mechanism ensures the robustness of the global model against such adversarial modifications. Additionally, to protect the privacy of local updates in the outlier detection mechanism, ByzSecAgg proposes a privacy-preserving distance computation method, inspired by ramp secret sharing and coded computing. For protection against adversarial behavior of type 2, first a vector commitment scheme is utilized in ByzSecAgg to ensure that users follow the protocol correctly when creating secret shares of their local updates in two different rounds. In addition, the ideas from error-correcting codes are used to ensure the correctness of the calculations of users.

Remark 2:

To eliminate outliers while minimizing communication requirements, ByzSecAgg uses two different rounds of secret sharing to securely calculate the pairwise distance between the local updates. It is worth noting that the second round of secret sharing is designed to only allow the server to calculate the pairwise distance between the local updates, rather than the pairwise distance between the partitions of local updates.

V Analysis of the Proposed Scheme

V-A Main results

In this subsection, we present the main results, achieved by ByzSecAgg described in Section IV.

Theorem 1.

We assume that (i) the cost function 𝔏𝔏\mathfrak{L} is three times differentiable with continuous derivatives, and is non-negative, i.e., 𝔏​(x)≥0𝔏𝑥0\mathfrak{L}(x)\geq 0; (ii) the learning rates satisfy ∑tδt=∞subscript𝑡subscript𝛿𝑡\sum_{t}\delta_{t}=\infty and ∑tδt2<∞subscript𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑡2\sum_{t}\delta_{t}^{2}<\infty; (iii) the second, the third, and the fourth moments of the quantized gradient estimator satisfy 𝔼Q,ζ​∥Qq​(𝐆​(𝐰g,ζ))∥r≤Ar+Br​∥𝐰g∥rsubscript𝔼𝑄𝜁superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑄𝑞𝐆subscript𝐰𝑔𝜁𝑟subscript𝐴𝑟subscript𝐵𝑟superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑔𝑟\mathbb{E}_{Q,\zeta}\lVert{Q_{q}(\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{w}_{g},\zeta))}\rVert^{r}\leq A_{r}+B_{r}\lVert{\mathbf{w}_{g}}\rVert^{r} for some constant Arsubscript𝐴𝑟A_{r} and Brsubscript𝐵𝑟B_{r}, where r∈2,3,4𝑟234r\in 2,3,4; (iv) there exist a constant 0≤γ<π/20𝛾𝜋20\leq\gamma<\pi/2 such that for all 𝐰g∈ℝLsubscript𝐰𝑔superscriptℝ𝐿\mathbf{w}_{g}\in\mathbb{R}^{L}, η​(N,A)​L​σ2​(𝐰g)+L4​q2≤∥∇𝔏​(𝐰g)∥​sin⁡γ𝜂𝑁𝐴𝐿superscript𝜎2subscript𝐰𝑔𝐿4superscript𝑞2delimited-∥∥∇𝔏subscript𝐰𝑔𝛾\eta(N,A)\sqrt{L\sigma^{2}(\mathbf{w}_{g})+\frac{L}{4q^{2}}}\leq\lVert{\nabla\mathfrak{L}(\mathbf{w}_{g})}\rVert\sin\gamma; (v) the gradient of the cost function 𝔏𝔏\mathfrak{L} satisfies that for ∥𝐰g∥2≥Rsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑔2𝑅\lVert{\mathbf{w}_{g}}\rVert^{2}\geq R, there exists constants ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 and 0≤θ<π/2−γ0𝜃𝜋2𝛾0\leq\theta<\pi/2-\gamma such that

∥∇𝔏​(𝐰g)∥≥ε>0,delimited-∥∥∇𝔏subscript𝐰𝑔𝜀0\displaystyle\lVert{\nabla\mathfrak{L}(\mathbf{w}_{g})}\rVert\geq\varepsilon>0,
𝐰gT​𝔏​(𝐰g)∥𝐰g∥​∥∇𝔏​(𝐰g)∥≥cos⁡θ.superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑇𝔏subscript𝐰𝑔delimited-∥∥subscript𝐰𝑔delimited-∥∥∇𝔏subscript𝐰𝑔𝜃\displaystyle\frac{\mathbf{w}_{g}^{T}\mathfrak{L}(\mathbf{w}_{g})}{\lVert{\mathbf{w}_{g}}\rVert\lVert{\nabla\mathfrak{L}(\mathbf{w}_{g})}\rVert}\geq\cos\theta.

Then, ByzSecAgg guarantees,

  • •

    Robustness against D𝐷D dropouts, and A𝐴A Byzantine adversarial users (Type 1 and Type 2) such that the trained model is (γ,A)𝛾𝐴(\gamma,A)-Byzantine resilient,

  • •

    The sequence of the gradients ∇𝔏​(𝐰g(t))∇𝔏superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑡\nabla\mathfrak{L}(\mathbf{w}_{g}^{(t)}) converges almost surely to zero,

  • •

    Any group of up to T𝑇T colluding users cannot extract any information about the local models of other honest users. The server cannot gain any information about local updates of the honest users, beyond the aggregation of them and pair-wise distances.

In addition, the communication loads in ByzSecAgg are as follows

Rserversubscript𝑅server\displaystyle R_{\text{server}} =(1+2​A+TK)​L+(T+A+K−12)​N​(N−1),absent12𝐴𝑇𝐾𝐿𝑇𝐴𝐾12𝑁𝑁1\displaystyle=\big{(}1+\frac{2A+T}{K}\big{)}L+(T+A+K-\frac{1}{2}){N(N-1)},
Rusersubscript𝑅user\displaystyle R_{\text{user}} ≤min⁡(2​NK,N)​L+(1+2​𝕀​(K>1))​N​(N−1)2,absent2𝑁𝐾𝑁𝐿12𝕀𝐾1𝑁𝑁12\displaystyle\leq\min(\frac{2N}{K},N)L+\big{(}1+2\mathbb{I}(K>1)\big{)}\frac{N(N-1)}{2},

symbols from 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p}, where 𝕀(.)\mathbb{I}(.) is an indicator function, for some K∈ℕ𝐾ℕK\in\mathbb{N} in [1:N−D+12−A−T]delimited-[]:1𝑁𝐷12𝐴𝑇[1:\frac{N-D+1}{2}-A-T] N≥2​A+D+max⁡(2​K+2​T−1,m+3)𝑁2𝐴𝐷2𝐾2𝑇1𝑚3N\geq~{}2A+D+\max(2K+2T-1,m+3) and m<N−2​A−D−2𝑚𝑁2𝐴𝐷2m~{}<~{}N-2A-D-2. Furthermore, the size of the commitment for each user in the achievable scheme remains constant, equal to (K+2​T)+𝕀​(K>1)​(2​K+2​T−2)𝐾2𝑇𝕀𝐾12𝐾2𝑇2(K+2T)+\mathbb{I}(K>1)(2K+2T-2), regardless of the size of the individual local updates, i.e., L𝐿L.

Remark 3:

As explained in Section IV, K𝐾K and m𝑚m are designed parameters. K𝐾K is the number of partitions of the local updates. By changing K𝐾K, one can change Rserversubscript𝑅serverR_{\text{server}} and Rusersubscript𝑅userR_{\text{user}}. One option is to choose K𝐾K such that the aggregation of the per-user communication load and the server communication load is minimized. On the other hand, m𝑚m is the number of users whose local updates are selected by the server for aggregation, as discussed in Subsection III-A and Section IV.

Proof.

In the following, we prove that ByzSecAgg satisfies the following conditions:
1) Correctness:

  • •

    Correctness of Commitments: The function h​(x)≜gx≜ℎ𝑥superscript𝑔𝑥h(x)\triangleq g^{x}, in (4), creates a bijection mapping between the finite field 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p} and cyclic group 𝔾𝔾\mathbb{G}, where g𝑔g is a generator of 𝔾𝔾\mathbb{G}. This function also has the linear homomorphic property which states that ∀a1,…,an∈𝔽pfor-allsubscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎𝑛subscript𝔽𝑝\forall a_{1},\dots,a_{n}\in\mathbb{F}_{p} and ∀x1,…,xn∈𝔽pfor-allsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝔽𝑝\forall x_{1},\dots,x_{n}\in\mathbb{F}_{p} we have

    h​(∑i=1nai​xi)=∏i=1nh​(xi)ai.ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑛ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖\displaystyle h\bigg{(}\sum_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}x_{i}\bigg{)}=\prod_{i=1}^{n}h(x_{i})^{a_{i}}.

    If the user is honest, it will share the evaluations of the same polynomial 𝐅n​(x)subscript𝐅𝑛𝑥\mathbf{F}_{n}(x) (𝐅~n(x)\big{(}\tilde{\mathbf{F}}_{n}(x) and Nn(j)(x))N_{n}^{(j)}(x)\big{)} in the first (second) round of secret sharing that it had initially committed to in Step 3. Due to the linearly homomorphic property of the commitments in (4), the verification step in (6) (in (9)) passes for the shares of the honest user.

  • •

    Correctness of the Final Result: The received vectors by the server at the end of Step 12 are different evaluations of polynomial 𝐅​(x)𝐅𝑥\mathbf{F}(x) of degree K+T−1𝐾𝑇1K+T-1 defined in (14). The correctness condition of the final result of ByzSecAgg is satisfied as the server can correctly recover ∑n∈𝒰s𝐰¯nsubscript𝑛subscript𝒰ssubscript¯𝐰𝑛\sum_{n\in\mathcal{U}_{\text{s}}}\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n} by utilizing the Reed-Solomon decoding after receiving K+T+2​A𝐾𝑇2𝐴K+T+2A outcomes from the users with at most A𝐴A adversarial outcomes.

2) Robustness against Byzantine Adversaries:

  • •

    Commitment Binding: The Discrete Logarithm (DL) Assumption [36] states that given a prime p𝑝p, a generator g𝑔g of 𝔾𝔾\mathbb{G}, and an element a∈𝔽p𝑎subscript𝔽𝑝a\in\mathbb{F}_{p}, no adversary with a probabilistic polynomial-time algorithm can compute a𝑎a given g𝑔g and gasuperscript𝑔𝑎g^{a}, i.e., Pr​[𝒜​(g,ga)=a]=ϵ​(κ)Prdelimited-[]𝒜𝑔superscript𝑔𝑎𝑎italic-ϵ𝜅\text{Pr}[\mathcal{A}\big{(}g,g^{a}\big{)}=a]=\epsilon(\kappa) (negligible) for any such adversarial algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}.

    In addition, consider the polynomial function q𝐰n,i​(x)subscript𝑞subscript𝐰𝑛𝑖𝑥q_{\mathbf{w}_{n,i}}(x) defined as

    q𝐰n,i​(x)≜[𝐰¯n,i]1+x​[𝐰¯n,i]2+⋯+xLK−1​[𝐰¯n,i]LK,≜subscript𝑞subscript𝐰𝑛𝑖𝑥subscriptdelimited-[]subscript¯𝐰𝑛𝑖1𝑥subscriptdelimited-[]subscript¯𝐰𝑛𝑖2⋯superscript𝑥𝐿𝐾1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript¯𝐰𝑛𝑖𝐿𝐾\displaystyle{q}_{\mathbf{w}_{n,i}}(x)\triangleq[\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n,i}]_{1}+x[\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n,i}]_{2}+\dots+x^{\frac{L}{K}-1}[\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n,i}]_{\frac{L}{K}},

    where [𝐰¯n,i]jsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript¯𝐰𝑛𝑖𝑗[\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n,i}]_{j} is the j𝑗j-th entry of the i𝑖i-th partition of the quantized local update 𝐰¯nsubscript¯𝐰𝑛\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n}. It can be verified that commitments Ci(n)superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑖𝑛C_{i}^{(n)} in (4) for i∈[K]𝑖delimited-[]𝐾i\in[K] are equal to gq𝐰n,i​(β)superscript𝑔subscript𝑞subscript𝐰𝑛𝑖𝛽g^{q_{\mathbf{w}_{n,i}}(\beta)}.

    By contradiction, assume that there exists an adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} that breaks the binding property of commitments. This means that the adversary creates two vectors 𝐰¯n,isubscript¯𝐰𝑛𝑖\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n,i} and 𝝂¯n,isubscript¯𝝂𝑛𝑖\bar{\bm{\nu}}_{n,i}, where 𝐰¯n,i≠𝝂¯n,isubscript¯𝐰𝑛𝑖subscript¯𝝂𝑛𝑖\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n,i}\neq\bar{\bm{\nu}}_{n,i} but Ci(n)≜gq𝐰n,i​(β)=gq𝝂n,i​(β)≜superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑖𝑛superscript𝑔subscript𝑞subscript𝐰𝑛𝑖𝛽superscript𝑔subscript𝑞subscript𝝂𝑛𝑖𝛽C_{i}^{(n)}\triangleq g^{q_{\mathbf{w}_{n,i}}(\beta)}=g^{q_{\bm{\nu}_{n,i}}(\beta)}.

    In this case, it can be shown that the adversary can break the DL assumption, which means it is able to recover secret β𝛽\beta by having gβsuperscript𝑔𝛽g^{\beta}. Define the polynomial function q~​(x)~𝑞𝑥\tilde{q}(x) as q𝐰n,i​(x)−q𝝂n,i​(x)subscript𝑞subscript𝐰𝑛𝑖𝑥subscript𝑞subscript𝝂𝑛𝑖𝑥q_{\mathbf{w}_{n,i}}(x)-q_{\bm{\nu}_{n,i}}(x). The corresponding commitment is equal to C~i(n)≜gq~​(β)=gq𝐰n,i​(β)/gq𝝂n,i​(β)=1≜superscriptsubscript~𝐶𝑖𝑛superscript𝑔~𝑞𝛽superscript𝑔subscript𝑞subscript𝐰𝑛𝑖𝛽superscript𝑔subscript𝑞subscript𝝂𝑛𝑖𝛽1\tilde{C}_{i}^{(n)}\triangleq g^{\tilde{q}(\beta)}=g^{q_{\mathbf{w}_{n,i}}(\beta)}/g^{q_{\bm{\nu}_{n,i}}(\beta)}=1 because the commitment scheme is homomorphic. Therefore, q~​(β)=0~𝑞𝛽0\tilde{q}(\beta)=0, which means that β𝛽\beta is a root of the polynomial q~​(x)~𝑞𝑥\tilde{q}(x). The adversary can easily solve the instance of the discrete logarithm problem and find the secret parameter β𝛽\beta by factoring q~​(x)~𝑞𝑥\tilde{q}(x) [37]. This implies that breaking the biding property would enable solving a problem that is assumed to be computationally difficult, reinforcing the notion that the commitment scheme must possess the biding property.

    Additionally, for the evaluation binding, we can present a similar argument. Let’s assume there exists an adversarial algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} that breaks the evaluation binding property of commitment C𝐶C and computes two different evaluations for 𝐅n​(x)subscript𝐅𝑛𝑥\mathbf{F}_{n}(x) in (5) at point α𝛼\alpha that satisfy Verify in (6). We can construct an algorithm ℬℬ\mathcal{B} that uses 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} to break the DL assumption. ℬℬ\mathcal{B} presents a DL instance (g,gβ,…,gβLK)𝑔superscript𝑔𝛽…superscript𝑔superscript𝛽𝐿𝐾(g,g^{\beta},\dots,g^{\beta^{\frac{L}{K}}}). Algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} outputs commitments C𝐶C and two distinct values for share, i.e., 𝐅n​(α)subscript𝐅𝑛𝛼\mathbf{F}_{n}(\alpha) and 𝐅n′​(α)subscriptsuperscript𝐅′𝑛𝛼\mathbf{F}^{\prime}_{n}(\alpha), that satisfy (6). Specifically, we have ∏j=1LK(gβj−1)[𝐅n​(α)]j=∏j=1LK(gβj−1)[𝐅n′​(α)]j=∏j=1K+T(Cj(n))αj−1superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗1𝐿𝐾superscriptsuperscript𝑔superscript𝛽𝑗1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐅𝑛𝛼𝑗superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗1𝐿𝐾superscriptsuperscript𝑔superscript𝛽𝑗1subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐅′𝑛𝛼𝑗superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗1𝐾𝑇superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑗𝑛superscript𝛼𝑗1\prod\limits_{j=1}^{\frac{L}{K}}(g^{\beta^{j-1}})^{[\mathbf{F}_{n}(\alpha)]_{j}}=\prod\limits_{j=1}^{\frac{L}{K}}(g^{\beta^{j-1}})^{[\mathbf{F}^{\prime}_{n}(\alpha)]_{j}}=\prod\limits_{j=1}^{K+T}(C_{j}^{({n})})^{\alpha^{j-1}}. Consequently, we observe that ∏j=1LK(gβj−1)[𝐅n​(α)]j−[𝐅n′​(α)]j=1superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗1𝐿𝐾superscriptsuperscript𝑔superscript𝛽𝑗1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐅𝑛𝛼𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐅′𝑛𝛼𝑗1\prod\limits_{j=1}^{\frac{L}{K}}(g^{\beta^{j-1}})^{[\mathbf{F}_{n}(\alpha)]_{j}-[\mathbf{F}^{\prime}_{n}(\alpha)]_{j}}=1. This implies that β𝛽\beta is a root of polynomial F′′​(x)=∑j=1LKxj−1​([𝐅n​(α)]j−[𝐅n′​(α)]j)superscript𝐹′′𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐿𝐾superscript𝑥𝑗1subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐅𝑛𝛼𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐅′𝑛𝛼𝑗{F}^{\prime\prime}(x)=\sum_{j=1}^{\frac{L}{K}}x^{j-1}([\mathbf{F}_{n}(\alpha)]_{j}-[\mathbf{F}^{\prime}_{n}(\alpha)]_{j}). Therefore, algorithm ℬℬ\mathcal{B} can compute β𝛽\beta by factoring F′′​(x)superscript𝐹′′𝑥{F}^{\prime\prime}(x) once it receives the results from 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. Thus, the success probability of solving the DL instance is the same as the success probability of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}.

  • •

    Malicious Computation Result (Type 2 Adversarial Attack): Here we discuss the adversarial attack of type 2 and how ByzSecAgg resolves it:

    • –

      The transmission of invalid secret shares in Step 4 and Step 6: this kind of attack is thwarted through the utilization of the commitments, in which the validity of secret shares at each round can be confirmed by verifying (6) and (9), provided that N−D≥2​A+1𝑁𝐷2𝐴1N-D\geq 2A+1.

    • –

      The transmission of incorrect pairwise distance of shares to the server in Step 8 or incorrect aggregation of the shares of selected users in Step 11: since the values sent at each of these two steps must represent different evaluation points of a certain polynomial, this kind of attack will be detected and corrected based on Reed-Solomon decoding algorithm with at most D𝐷D erasures and at most A𝐴A errors, provided that N−D≥2​(K+T+A)−1𝑁𝐷2𝐾𝑇𝐴1N-D\geq 2(K+T+A)-1 in Step 8 and N−D≥K+T+2​A𝑁𝐷𝐾𝑇2𝐴N-D\geq K+T+2A in Step 11.

  • •

    Global Model Resiliency (Type 1 Adversarial Attack): Byzantine users have the ability to modify their local updates to manipulate the global model and can send arbitrary vectors as their local updates to the server. Additionally, in line with classical assumptions in machine learning literature, each data sample used for computing the local update is uniformly and independently drawn by honest users. To detect outliers, ByzSecAgg uses the multi-Krum algorithm introduced in Subsection III-A. Instead of the estimator 𝐆​(𝐰g(t),ζn(t))𝐆superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑛𝑡\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{w}_{g}^{(t)},\zeta_{n}^{(t)}), in the proposed scheme, the local update of the honest user is created using the quantized estimator Qq​(𝐆​(𝐰g(t),ζn(t)))subscript𝑄𝑞𝐆superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑛𝑡Q_{q}(\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{w}_{g}^{(t)},\zeta_{n}^{(t)})). In [24], it is demonstrated that even when the multi-krum algorithm is applied to the quantized vector Qq​(𝐰n)subscript𝑄𝑞subscript𝐰𝑛Q_{q}(\mathbf{w}_{n}) (as used in Step 1 of the proposed scheme), it remains (α,A)𝛼𝐴(\alpha,A)-Byzantine resilient and the sequence of the gradients converges almost surely to zero. This is due to the fact that the quantization is unbiased and has a bounded variance. According to Subsection III-A if m<N−2​A−D−2𝑚𝑁2𝐴𝐷2m<N-2A-D-2, the multi-Krum algorithm can prevent this type of attack and ensure that the scheme is (γ,A)𝛾𝐴(\gamma,A)-Byzantine resilient and guarantees the convergence. Note that the first five conditions in Theorem 1, i.e., (i)-(v), are essential in the convergence proof of multi-Krum algorithm (see [18, 24]).

3) Privacy Constraint:

  • •

    Hiding Property: For the sake of contradiction, suppose there exists an adversarial algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} that can break the hiding property of commitment C𝐶C and correctly compute vector 𝝂∈𝔽p𝝂subscript𝔽𝑝\bm{\nu}\in\mathbb{F}_{p}. We will demonstrate how to utilize 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} to construct another algorithm ℬℬ\mathcal{B} that can break the Discrete Logarithm (DL) assumption.
    Let (g,ga)𝑔superscript𝑔𝑎(g,g^{a}) be a DL instance that ℬℬ\mathcal{B} aims to solve. ℬℬ\mathcal{B} selects a random β~∈𝔽pL~𝛽subscriptsuperscript𝔽𝐿𝑝\tilde{\beta}\in\mathbb{F}^{L}_{p} and computes (g,gβ~,…,gβ~L−1)𝑔superscript𝑔~𝛽…superscript𝑔superscript~𝛽𝐿1(g,g^{\tilde{\beta}},\dots,g^{\tilde{\beta}^{L-1}}). It then considers a vector 𝝂=[a,ν1,ν2,…,νL]𝝂𝑎subscript𝜈1subscript𝜈2…subscript𝜈𝐿\bm{\nu}=[a,\nu_{1},\nu_{2},\dots,\nu_{L}], where ν1,ν2,…,νL−1∈𝔽psubscript𝜈1subscript𝜈2…subscript𝜈𝐿1subscript𝔽𝑝\nu_{1},\nu_{2},\dots,\nu_{L-1}\in\mathbb{F}_{p} are chosen arbitrarily, and the first entry of the vector a𝑎a is the answer for the DL instance. Since ℬℬ\mathcal{B} knows gasuperscript𝑔𝑎g^{a}, it can compute the vector commitment as C=ga.g∑i=1L−1​νi​β~iformulae-sequence𝐶superscript𝑔𝑎superscript𝑔𝑖superscript1𝐿1subscript𝜈𝑖superscript~𝛽𝑖C=g^{a}.g^{\sum{i=1}^{L-1}\nu_{i}\tilde{\beta}^{i}} and sends it to 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. Upon receiving the commitment, 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} computes and returns vector 𝝂𝝂\bm{\nu}. At this point, ℬℬ\mathcal{B} can extract the solution a𝑎a, as it corresponds to the DL instance. Thus, the success probability of solving the DL instance using ℬℬ\mathcal{B} is equivalent to the success probability of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. The aforementioned construction illustrates that if an adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} can break the hiding property of commitment C𝐶C, then we can utilize it to construct another algorithm ℬℬ\mathcal{B} capable of breaking the DL assumption.

  • •

    Privacy of Individual Local Updates: The hiding property of the commitments ensures that neither the server nor any user can compute the local model 𝐰¯nsubscript¯𝐰𝑛\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n} (as well as noise vectors 𝐳nsubscript𝐳𝑛\mathbf{z}_{n} and 𝐳~nsubscript~𝐳𝑛\tilde{\mathbf{z}}_{n}) from the commitments Ci(n)superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑖𝑛C_{i}^{(n)} in (4). Thus, by considering the messages exchanged during the scheme, it is sufficient to stablish the privacy of each local update against a group of up to T𝑇T colluding users, denoted by set 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}. Denote the colluding users by U~1,U~2,…,U~Tsubscript~𝑈1subscript~𝑈2…subscript~𝑈𝑇\tilde{U}_{1},\tilde{U}_{2},\dots,\tilde{U}_{T}. Let us define the set of messages received by U~isubscript~𝑈𝑖\tilde{U}_{i} as ℳU~isubscriptℳsubscript~𝑈𝑖\mathcal{M}_{\tilde{U}_{i}}, which includes two types of messages: 𝐬n,isubscript𝐬𝑛𝑖\mathbf{s}_{n,i}, 𝐬~n,isubscript~𝐬𝑛𝑖\tilde{\mathbf{s}}_{n,i} and Nn,ijsuperscriptsubscript𝑁𝑛𝑖𝑗N_{n,i}^{j} for n,j∈[N]∖{𝒯∪𝒟}𝑛𝑗delimited-[]𝑁𝒯𝒟n,j\in[N]\setminus\{\mathcal{T}\cup\mathcal{D}\}, j≠n𝑗𝑛j\neq n. These messages correspond to the shares from the first and second round of secret sharing in Step 4 and Step 6, respectively. According to (5) and (7), the fact that the random vectors are chosen uniformly and independently at random from 𝔽pLKsuperscriptsubscript𝔽𝑝𝐿𝐾\mathbb{F}_{p}^{\frac{L}{K}}, and directly from the privacy guarantee in ramp secret sharing [29], for n∈[N]∖𝒯𝑛delimited-[]𝑁𝒯n\in[N]\setminus\mathcal{T}, we have

    Pr​(𝐰¯n=𝝂|ℳU~i,i∈[T])Prsubscript¯𝐰𝑛conditional𝝂subscriptℳsubscript~𝑈𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑇\displaystyle\text{Pr}\big{(}\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n}=\bm{\nu}\big{|}\mathcal{M}_{\tilde{U}_{i}},i\in[T]\big{)}
    =Pr​(𝐰¯n=𝝂|𝐬n,i,𝐬~n,i,i∈[T])absentPrsubscript¯𝐰𝑛conditional𝝂subscript𝐬𝑛𝑖subscript~𝐬𝑛𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑇\displaystyle=\text{Pr}\big{(}\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n}=\bm{\nu}\big{|}\mathbf{s}_{n,i},\tilde{\mathbf{s}}_{n,i},i\in[T]\big{)}
    =Pr​(𝐰¯n=𝝂),absentPrsubscript¯𝐰𝑛𝝂\displaystyle=\text{Pr}\big{(}\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n}=\bm{\nu}\big{)},

    which means that the colluding users cannot gain any further information about the local updates of the other users.

    Furthermore, the server is also provided with d¯i,j(n)superscriptsubscript¯𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑛\bar{d}_{i,j}^{(n)} for i<j∈[N]𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑁i<j\in[N] and 𝐬n=∑n~∈𝒰s𝐬n~,nsubscript𝐬𝑛subscript~𝑛subscript𝒰𝑠subscript𝐬~𝑛𝑛\mathbf{s}_{n}=\sum_{\tilde{n}\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}\mathbf{s}_{\tilde{n},n} from users n∈[N]∖𝒟𝑛delimited-[]𝑁𝒟n\in[N]\setminus\mathcal{D}, from which it can reconstruct d¯i,j(n)​(x)superscriptsubscript¯𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑛𝑥\bar{d}_{i,j}^{(n)}(x) as defined in (11), as well as the polynomial function 𝐅​(x)𝐅𝑥\mathbf{F}(x) as defined in (14). Therefore, from 𝐅​(x)𝐅𝑥\mathbf{F}(x) the server can recover the aggregation 𝐰¯=∑n∈𝒰s𝐰¯n¯𝐰subscript𝑛subscript𝒰ssubscript¯𝐰𝑛\bar{\mathbf{w}}=\sum_{n\in\mathcal{U}_{\text{s}}}\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{n} and from the coefficient of xK−1superscript𝑥𝐾1x^{K-1} in d¯i,j(n)​(x)superscriptsubscript¯𝑑𝑖𝑗𝑛𝑥\bar{d}_{i,j}^{(n)}(x) it can recover the mutual distance ∥𝐰¯i−𝐰¯j∥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript¯𝐰𝑖subscript¯𝐰𝑗2\lVert{\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{i}-\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{j}}\rVert^{2}. It is important to note that due to the inclusion of random noises during the computation in Step 8 by each user, the server cannot retrieve any other details about the local models. The only information that can be obtained are the mutual distances between the models, which play a vital role in outlier detection.

Communication Loads in the Proposed Scheme:
According to Step 12, the total number of vectors that are needed to be received by the server to recover the final aggregation is T+K+2​A𝑇𝐾2𝐴T+K+2A, each of size LK𝐿𝐾\frac{L}{K} symbols. Moreover, in order to recover the pairwise distance di,jsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑗d_{i,j} between 𝐰¯isubscript¯𝐰𝑖\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{i} and 𝐰¯jsubscript¯𝐰𝑗\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{j}, the server needs 2​(K+T+A)−12𝐾𝑇𝐴12(K+T+A)-1 symbols of size a single field element from the users, for i,j∈[N],i≠jformulae-sequence𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑁𝑖𝑗i,j\in[N],i\neq j. Thus, the server communication load in ByzSecAgg is Rserver≤(1+2​A+TK)​L+(T+A+K−12)​N​(N−1)subscript𝑅server12𝐴𝑇𝐾𝐿𝑇𝐴𝐾12𝑁𝑁1R_{\text{server}}\leq\big{(}1+\frac{2A+T}{K}\big{)}L+(T+A+K-\frac{1}{2})N(N-1), where the inequality is a result of the presence of dropped-out users in the setting.

In ByzSecAgg, each user participates in two rounds of secret sharing. In the first round, they send one vector of size LK𝐿𝐾\frac{L}{K} symbols and in the second round, they send one vector of size LK+N𝐿𝐾𝑁\frac{L}{K}+N symbols to each of the other users. Additionally, each user sends one vector of size LK𝐿𝐾\frac{L}{K} symbols to the server. However, if K=1𝐾1K=1, the second round of secret sharing is not performed. In addition, each user sends at most N​(N−1)2𝑁𝑁12\frac{N(N-1)}{2} pair-wise distances of size a single field element to the server. Thus, the per-user communication load in ByzSecAgg is upper-bounded as Ruser≤2​NK​L+3​N​(N−1)2subscript𝑅user2𝑁𝐾𝐿3𝑁𝑁12R_{\text{user}}\leq\frac{2N}{K}L+\frac{3N(N-1)}{2}. In addition, the commitment size for each user is only K+2​T𝐾2𝑇K+2T symbols when K=1𝐾1K=1, and 3​K+4​T−23𝐾4𝑇23K+4T-2 symbols when K>1𝐾1K>1, where each symbol has the size of a single group element.

Therefore, the communication loads Rserversubscript𝑅serverR_{\text{server}} and Rusersubscript𝑅userR_{\text{user}} in Theorem 1 are achieved. Additionally, according to discussions in Subsection V to meet all requirements, the inequality

N≥2​A+D+max⁡(2​K+2​T−1,m+3),𝑁2𝐴𝐷2𝐾2𝑇1𝑚3\displaystyle N\geq 2A+D+\max(2K+2T-1,m+3), (16)

must be fulfilled. In addition, the following condition

1≤K≤N−D+12−A−T,1𝐾𝑁𝐷12𝐴𝑇\displaystyle 1\leq K\leq\frac{N-D+1}{2}-A-T, (17)

must be satisfied for the number of partitions of the local updates, where K∈ℤ𝐾ℤK\in\mathbb{Z}. ∎

V-B Comparison with BREA [24]

The comparison results between ByzSecAgg and BREA [24] are summarized in Table I, which highlights the differences between the two schemes based on the defined parameters. This subsection presents a comparison between these two schemes in terms of communication loads in various simulation scenarios.

Figure 1 compares the communication loads, measured in symbols, between ByzSecAgg and BREA. The simulation involves N=1000𝑁1000N=1000 users, with T=0.1​N𝑇0.1𝑁T=0.1N colluding users, A=0.1​N𝐴0.1𝑁A=0.1N Byzantine adversaries, and D=0.2​N𝐷0.2𝑁D=0.2N potential dropouts. The comparison focuses on three metrics: (a) per-user communication load, (b) server communication load, and (c) commitment size. Various neural networks, including GoogleNet [38], ResNet [39], and AlexNet [40], with different parameter numbers (L𝐿L) are considered. The results demonstrate that ByzSecAgg achieves order-wise reduction in communication loads and commitment sizes compared to BREA. In this comparison, for ByzSecAgg, the number of partitions (K𝐾K) is selected to minimize the aggregation of per-user communication load and server communication load. As it is shown, the commitment size of the proposed scheme remains constant and is not influenced by the length of local updates. The slight variations observed in the graph are due to changes in the selected value for K𝐾K.

Figure 2 illustrates the communication loads of the two schemes as the number of users (N𝑁N) varies. The simulation considers L=21.8​M𝐿21.8𝑀L=21.8M parameters, T=0.1​N𝑇0.1𝑁T=0.1N colluding users, A=0.1​N𝐴0.1𝑁A=0.1N Byzantine adversaries, and D=0.2​N𝐷0.2𝑁D=0.2N dropouts. Similarly, in this comparison, for ByzSecAgg the number of partitions (K𝐾K) is selected to minimize the aggregation of per-user communication load and server communication load. Note that compared to BREA, the proposed scheme achieves the same performance in terms of convergence and resilience properties.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we propose ByzSecAgg, an efficient secure aggregation scheme for federated learning that mitigates Byzantine adversarial attacks while protecting the privacy of individual local updates. ByzSecAgg employs techniques such as ramp secret sharing and coded computing to reduce communication loads and enable secure computation of pairwise distances, which are used for distance-based outlier detection algorithms. Additionally, we use a linear commitment scheme with a constant commitment size to ensure message integrity during the protocol and protect against adversarial behaviors of Byzantine users. In terms of communication loads, ByzSecAgg outperforms the state-of-the-art BREA and offers the advantage of a constant commitment size, regardless of local update sizes. Furthermore, it achieves the same level of performance in terms of convergence and resilience properties.
